Evaluate prediction results

Source: R/evaluation.R
evaluate_predictions.Rd

Evaluates the performance of different prediction methods by computing confusion matrices, accuracy metrics, and statistical tests.

Usage

evaluate_predictions(seurat_object)

Arguments

seurat_object

A Seurat object containing prediction results in metadata.

Value

A list containing:

  • direct_table: Confusion matrix for direct predictions

  • threshold_table: Confusion matrix for threshold-based predictions

  • svm_table: Confusion matrix for SVM predictions

  • direct_accuracy: Accuracy metrics for direct predictions

  • svm_accuracy: Accuracy metrics for SVM predictions

  • chi_direct: Chi-squared test results for direct predictions

  • chi_svm: Chi-squared test results for SVM predictions

Details

This function performs a comprehensive evaluation of prediction results by comparing predicted cell culture media conditions against actual conditions. It supports multiple prediction methods including direct similarity-based, threshold-based, and SVM predictions.

The evaluation process includes:

  1. Computing confusion matrices for each prediction method

  2. Calculating accuracy metrics (total correct, percentage) by sample

  3. Performing chi-squared tests to assess statistical significance

  4. Organizing results into a structured list for easy access

Confusion matrices show the relationship between actual and predicted conditions, revealing which conditions are commonly confused with each other. Accuracy metrics provide an overall assessment of prediction performance, while chi-squared tests determine whether the predictions are significantly better than random chance.

The function expects prediction results to be stored in the Seurat object metadata with the following column names:

  • "predicted_sample_1": Direct similarity-based predictions

  • "predicted_sample_2": Threshold-based predictions

  • "classification_pred": SVM-based predictions

Examples

evaluation_results <- evaluate_predictions(seurat_object)
#> Error: object 'seurat_object' not found
